item.title: Porridge oats recall due to possible presence of pellets
item.description: The Food Safety Authority of Ireland has issued a recall notice on Dunnes Stores organic porridge oats on its 1kg pack size, due to what is says is the "possible presence of clear plastic pellets".
item.source:markdown: The Food Safety Authority of Ireland has issued a recall notice on Dunnes Stores organic porridge oats on its 1kg pack size, due to what is says is the "possible presence of clear plastic pellets".

item.title: Bill introduced to rename Dublin Airport after Lemass
item.description: A bill to officially rename Dublin Airport after former taoiseach Seán Lemass has been moved to a second stage.
item.source:markdown: A bill to officially rename Dublin Airport after former taoiseach Seán Lemass has been moved to a second stage.

item.title: Pope Leo headed to Turkey and Lebanon for 1st trip abroad as leader of Catholic Church
item.description: Pope Leo will embark on his first trip outside Italy as the leader of the Catholic Church on Thursday, traveling to Turkey and Lebanon, where he is expected to make appeals for peace in the region and urge unity among long-divided Christian churches.
item.source:markdown:
![A large banner with an image of Pope Leo XIV](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/45729b7d-aea9-4c02-b74c-67535454827d,1764107247323/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28299%2C118%2C2638%2C1483%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Pope Leo will embark on his first trip outside Italy as the leader of the Catholic Church on Thursday, traveling to Turkey and Lebanon, where he is expected to make appeals for peace in the region and urge unity among long-divided Christian churches.

item.title: Enoch Burke arrested and brought to Mountjoy Prison
item.description: Enoch Burke has been arrested and brought to Mountjoy Prison on foot of an order issued by the High Court last week which directed his imprisonment for contempt of court.
item.source:markdown: Enoch Burke has been arrested and brought to Mountjoy Prison on foot of an order issued by the High Court last week which directed his imprisonment for contempt of court.

item.title: Voice of peace and hope: Pope Leo's visit to Türkiye and Lebanon
item.description:
The director of the Holy See Press Office presents Pope Leo XIV’s first apostolic journey that takes him to Türkiye and Lebanon, emphasising ecumenical commemoration, interreligious dialogue, and support for local Christian communities. The visit includes historic and symbolic encounters, meetings with civil and religious leaders, and gestures of solidarity amid regional challenges.

Read all

item.title: UN: 50,000 women killed in one year
item.description:
On the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, new UN figures highlight the scale of gender-based violence. As online abuse is on the rise, Sister Abby Avelino of Talitha Kum shines the light on the plight of millions of trafficked women and girls.

Read all

item.title: Man to be sentenced for dangerous driving causing death
item.description: A 21-year-old man will be sentenced next month for dangerous driving causing the death of his friend whose body lay undiscovered in a car for some time after it slammed into the back of a truck two years ago.
item.source:markdown: A 21-year-old man will be sentenced next month for dangerous driving causing the death of his friend whose body lay undiscovered in a car for some time after it slammed into the back of a truck two years ago.

item.title: Can 3D printing limbs help Gaza's war wounded?
item.description: Gaza now has more child amputees per capita than anywhere else in the world. CBC News chief correspondent Adrienne Arsenault meets with organizations in Cairo trying to help, including a Canadian non-profit organization hoping to provide 3D printed prosthetics.

item.title: Minister O'Brien writes to NTA on Uber's fixed pricing

item.title: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro begins serving 27-year prison sentence
item.description: Brazil's Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered former president Jair Bolsonaro to begin a prison sentence of more than 27 years for plotting a coup in 2022, according to a court document.

item.title: Abducted Nigerian schoolgirls rescued, president says
item.description: All 24 schoolgirls who were  abducted by armed assailants from a school last week in Kebbi  in northwestern Nigeria have been rescued, the country's president announced Tuesday.

All 24 schoolgirls who were abducted by armed assailants from a school last week in Kebbi in northwestern Nigeria have been rescued, the country's president announced Tuesday.

item.title: Campaign for younger blood donors launched at Croke Park

item.title: Israel isn't sure latest human remains returned by Hamas are those of a hostage

item.title: Campbell's exec on leave after allegedly mocking 'poor people' who eat its soup
item.description: A lawsuit filed by a former security analyst at Campbell's alleges he was fired for reporting inappropriate conduct by a senior executive, including an hour-long rant in which the executive allegedly called the company's products "s--t for f---ing poor people" in a secret recording.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Sentencing adjourned for former TD guilty of drug driving
item.description: A sentencing hearing for a former TD, who has admitted to driving under the influence of cocaine, has been adjourned until next month. Colm Keaveney pleaded guilty to a charge of drug driving and to two other charges of driving without insurance at Tuam District Court in September.

item.title: Despite ongoing discrimination, women entrepreneurs are reshaping the Global South, with crucial support from the UN
item.description: Exceptional women business leaders such as African engineer-turned-entrepreneur Norah Magero are demonstrating how lived experience and ingenuity, backed by United Nations support, can turn promising ideas into successful companies, even in societies where their voices have long been sidelined.

item.title: Gaza women are ‘last line of protection’ for their families amid attacks, hunger and harsh winter
item.description: Women in Gaza are ensuring their families’ survival “with nothing but courage and exhausted hands” while violence continues and essentials remain in short supply, the UN’s gender equality agency warned on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: Women in Gaza are ensuring their families’ survival “with nothing but courage and exhausted hands” while violence continues and essentials remain in short supply, the UN’s gender equality agency warned on Tuesday.

item.title: Gaza facing worst economic collapse ever recorded, UN trade agency warns
item.description: The Occupied Palestinian Territory is now in its deepest economic crisis ever recorded, with Gaza suffering an “unprecedented and catastrophic” collapse, according to a new report from the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) presented in Geneva on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: The Occupied Palestinian Territory is now in its deepest economic crisis ever recorded, with Gaza suffering an “unprecedented and catastrophic” collapse, according to a new report from the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) presented in Geneva on Tuesday.

item.title: Global HIV response facing worst setback in decades, UNAIDS warns
item.description: The global response to HIV is facing its most serious setback in decades, UNAIDS warned on Tuesday, as abrupt funding cuts and a deteriorating human rights environment disrupt prevention and treatment services across dozens of countries.
item.source:markdown: The global response to HIV is facing its most serious setback in decades, UNAIDS warned on Tuesday, as abrupt funding cuts and a deteriorating human rights environment disrupt prevention and treatment services across dozens of countries.

item.title: Over 600 million children exposed to violence at home, UNICEF warns
item.description: More than one in four children globally – around 610 million – live with mothers who have experienced physical, emotional or sexual abuse by an intimate partner in the past year, making violence a part of their everyday lives, according to new data released by the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: More than one in four children globally – around 610 million – live with mothers who have experienced physical, emotional or sexual abuse by an intimate partner in the past year, making violence a part of their everyday lives, according to new data released by the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) on Tuesday.

item.title: On International Day of Solidarity, UN urges greater support and aid for Palestinians
item.description: For over two years, tens of thousands of people have been killed in Gaza. The enclave faces its most severe economic collapse in history, and even amid a fragile ceasefire, children continue to die.
item.source:markdown: For over two years, tens of thousands of people have been killed in Gaza. The enclave faces its most severe economic collapse in history, and even amid a fragile ceasefire, children continue to die.

item.title: Majority of crimes last year committed by re-offenders
item.description: Four of every five thefts, frauds, robberies and deception offences solved last year were committed by or involved an offender with a prior criminal history.

item.title: Ukraine dials down US peace plan but core issues remain
item.description: After last week's US ultimatum to accept an unfavourable peace deal, Ukrainian officials have strengthened Kyiv's hand after intense discussions with US officials in Geneva last Sunday. But the core issues of territory, NATO membership and security guarantees remain undecided

item.title: Same-sex marriage should be recognised in bloc - EU court
item.description: The EU's highest court has ruled that same-sex marriages must be respected throughout the bloc and rebuked Poland for refusing to recognise a marriage between two of its citizens that took place in Germany.
item.source:markdown: The EU's highest court has ruled that same-sex marriages must be respected throughout the bloc and rebuked Poland for refusing to recognise a marriage between two of its citizens that took place in Germany.

item.title: Graham Linehan cleared of harassing transgender activist
item.description: Father Ted co-creator Graham Linehan has been found guilty of the criminal damage of a transgender woman's phone at an event in London last year, but not guilty of harassment.
item.source:markdown: Father Ted co-creator Graham Linehan has been found guilty of the criminal damage of a transgender woman's phone at an event in London last year, but not guilty of harassment.

item.title: Doctrine of the Faith: Monogamy is not a limitation but a promise of the infinite
item.description:
The doctrinal Note Una caro. In Praise of Monogamy has been published, exploring the value of marriage as an “exclusive union and mutual belonging.” It highlights the importance of conjugal charity and attentiveness to the poor, and condemns all forms of violence, both physical and psychological. In an individualistic and consumerist age, young people must be educated to understand love as responsibility and trust in the other.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The doctrinal Note Una caro. In Praise of Monogamy has been published, exploring the value of marriage as an “exclusive union and mutual belonging.” It highlights the importance of conjugal charity and attentiveness to the poor, and condemns all forms of violence, both physical and psychological. In an individualistic and consumerist age, young people must be educated to understand love as responsibility and trust in the other.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-11/doctrine-of-faith-monogamy-not-limitation-but-promise-infinite.html)

item.title: Legal challenge to MetroLink to cause 'inevitable delay'

item.title: Sudanese army, paramilitary fighters haven't signed onto truce plan, Trump adviser says
item.description: The United States has presented Sudan's warring parties with a proposal for a truce but neither side has formally accepted it, U.S. envoy Massad Boulos said Tuesday, as the army accused its rivals of staging an attack despite declaring a ceasefire.

The United States has presented Sudan's warring parties with a proposal for a truce but neither side has formally accepted it, U.S. envoy Massad Boulos said Tuesday, as the army accused its rivals of staging an attack despite declaring a ceasefire.

item.title: Russian attacks kill at least 7 in Ukraine, as flurry of talks on peace plan proceed
item.description: Russia launched a wave of attacks on Ukraine on Tuesday, killing at least seven people in overnight strikes that hit city buildings and energy infrastructure, while a Ukrainian attack in southern Russia killed three people and damaged homes, authorities said. Meanwhile talks aimed at putting a halt to the hostilities were taking place in Europe and Abu Dhabi.

item.title: Some wins for multilateralism at the G20 — and big questions about its long-term future
item.description: The G20 summit is supposed to be the pinnacle of multilateralism: the idea that nations can co-operate, compromise and co-ordinate for the greater good. But a lot has changed in the past two decades.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Spotlight on Gaza, the West Bank and Lebanon
item.description: The Security Council is meeting against the backdrop of Gaza’s fragile ceasefire, with ambassadors expected to urge Israel and Hamas to stick to their commitments amid renewed violence and deepening humanitarian needs. The session is likely to focus on safeguarding the truce, easing aid access restrictions and sustaining political momentum. With tensions also rising in the occupied West Bank and southern Lebanon, the meeting will test whether the Council can help stabilise the situation and keep alive a credible path towards Palestinian self-determination. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. For in-depth meetings coverage, go here.
item.source:markdown: The Security Council is meeting against the backdrop of Gaza’s fragile ceasefire, with ambassadors expected to urge Israel and Hamas to stick to their commitments amid renewed violence and deepening humanitarian needs. The session is likely to focus on safeguarding the truce, easing aid access restrictions and sustaining political momentum. With tensions also rising in the occupied West Bank and southern Lebanon, the meeting will test whether the Council can help stabilise the situation and keep alive a credible path towards Palestinian self-determination. item.title: Pope Leo consolidates governance reform for Vatican City Commission
item.description:
With a Motu Proprio, Pope Leo XIV has abrogated Article 8 n. 1 of the previous Fundamental Law of Vatican City State, which had allowed only cardinals to serve as president of the Commission, a position currently held by Sister Raffaella Petrini. The Pope, therefore, consolidates a change wanted by Francis and resolves an issue that had emerged due to increasingly “complex and pressing” governance needs.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
With a Motu Proprio, Pope Leo XIV has abrogated Article 8 n. 1 of the previous Fundamental Law of Vatican City State, which had allowed only cardinals to serve as president of the Commission, a position currently held by Sister Raffaella Petrini. The Pope, therefore, consolidates a change wanted by Francis and resolves an issue that had emerged due to increasingly “complex and pressing” governance needs.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/pope-leo-xiv-motu-proprio-presidency-vatican-city-commission.html)

item.title: It would be foolish to underestimate what Trump is capable of, says author Louise Penny
item.description: Louise Penny’s new novel explores a sinister plot to make Canada the 51st state — but she’s keen to point out that she wrote it before Donald Trump was re-elected as U.S. president. She spoke with Matt Galloway live on stage at the Haskell Free Library, right on the U.S.-Canada border.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman and man talk on a stage](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f2056e70-11bd-485c-80ab-41a4b4e23934,1763738454880/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%2863%2C632%2C5672%2C3190%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Louise Penny’s new novel explores a sinister plot to make Canada the 51st state — but she’s keen to point out that she wrote it before Donald Trump was re-elected as U.S. president. She spoke with Matt Galloway live on stage at the Haskell Free Library, right on the U.S.-Canada border.

item.title: Beirut's Maronite Archbishop: The Pope’s presence is enough for us
item.description:
The Maronite Archbishop of Beirut, Paul Abdel Sater, looks forward to Pope Leo XIV's upcoming visit to Lebanon. He upholds the Pope's continuing closeness to the country and says his mere presence will provide huge encouragement to the population.

item.title: 60 years of Nostra Aetate: from a seed of hope a great tree has grown
item.description:
Participants from numerous countries and various religious traditions gathered at the international symposium "Nostra Aetate: 60 Years Later" held at the Pontifical University of the Holy Cross in Rome. Cardinal George Koovakad, Prefect of the Dicastery for Interreligious Dialogue and one of the speakers, emphasized that interreligious dialogue must receive greater attention on the international stage and that the spirit of Nostra Aetate remains essential for contemporary peacebuilding efforts.

Read all

item.title: Zelenskyy says Ukraine may face 'very difficult choice' as U.S. gives deadline on peace plan
item.description: Ukraine may face a hard choice at a pivotal point in its almost four-year fight to defeat Russia's full-scale invasion, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told Ukrainians in a national address Friday, pledging to hold constructive discussions with Washington on a U.S. peace proposal in what he called "truly one of the most difficult moments in our history."

item.description: A draft 28-point plan backed by US President Donald Trump would require Ukraine to offer territorial and security concessions to Moscow, while Russia would be readmitted to the G8 group and receive sanctions relief.

item.title: Pilot killed as Indian fighter jet crashes at Dubai Air Show
item.description: An Indian HAL Tejas crashed Friday local time while flying a demonstration flight for a crowd at the Dubai Air Show, sending black smoke over the Maktoum International Airport in the Emirates. It wasn't immediately clear if the pilot ejected the aircraft.

item.title: Why Canada is winning the travel trade war with the U.S.
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump’s divisive politics, tariffs and heightened border security have helped drive a decline in international tourism spending in the U.S. Meanwhile, polls and industry experts suggest a surge of Canadian patriotism and perceptions of Canada as a safe and friendly destination helped drive a record-breaking summer for tourism in the country.
item.source:markdown:
![Air passengers at airport walk by Canadians flags. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7e09d118-e088-4ce6-a58e-accc2d68ed46,1763588697710/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28512%2C676%2C3798%2C2136%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Garda, others held over €100k of missing drugs released

item.title: Talks at WRC over school secretary pensions break down
item.description: Talks at the Workplace Relations Commission aimed at resolving a pensions dispute involving school secretaries and caretakers have broken down. The negotiations ended this evening without agreement, and the workers' trade union, Fórsa, said it wants the matter to be referred to the Labour Court.
item.source:markdown: Talks at the Workplace Relations Commission aimed at resolving a pensions dispute involving school secretaries and caretakers have broken down. item.title: $54.7M US sale of Frida Kahlo self-portrait shatters auction record for female artists

item.title: Actor Kevin Spacey says he's living out of hotels after losing Hollywood roles
item.description: Several men accused Spacey of making unwanted sexual advances during the #MeToo movement. While none of the allegations were proven in court, Spacey says the allegations have kept Hollywood at bay.

item.title: The Fugees' Pras Michel handed 14-year sentence for illegal donations to Obama re-election campaign

item.title: U.K. government moves to ban inflated resale of tickets for entertainment and sports events
item.description: The U.K. government announced that it is banning the resale of concert, sports, and live event tickets above face value. Fans there could be saved from shelling out around $206 million annually for tickets.
item.source:markdown:
![A hand extracts three concert tickets from a pocket, a common tactic used in ticket scalping](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/96c36ddf-f6e0-4f4a-8fdb-c5041b264340,1763708610418/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C386%2C7360%2C4140%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The U.K. government announced that it is banning the resale of concert, sports, and live event tickets above face value. Fans there could be saved from shelling out around $206 million annually for tickets.

item.title: Trump administration touts plan for new oil drilling off California, Florida
item.description: The Trump administration announced on Thursday new oil drilling off the California and Florida coasts for the first time in decades, advancing a project that critics say could harm coastal communities and ecosystems, as U.S. President Donald Trump seeks to expand U.S. oil production.

item.title: Warner Music and Udio settle lawsuit, agree to build new AI music platform
item.description: The deal settles Warner's copyright infringement claims against AI music generation platform Udio, and will allow the platform to train its AI on licensed and authorized music from its artists. This agreement closely mirrors one signed weeks ago between Udio and Universal Music Group, and comes as AI generated songs and artists have been increasingly popping up on streaming platforms and rising on music charts.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Spotlight on rising casualties in Ukraine
item.description: The Security Council is holding a rare open briefing on Ukraine following days of deadly attacks by Russia on civilian areas and amid a renewed US mission to Kyiv in search of a peace deal. With attacks on energy infrastructure soaring and civilian casualties climbing, Council members have demanded answers and action. Can the Council increase pressure on veto-wielding Moscow, secure better protection and aid for civilians, and push toward an elusive ceasefire? Follow live below, find full UN meetings coverage here; UN News app users can click here.

item.title: Security Council’s veto power is ‘poster child’ of global gridlock, says Baerbock
item.description: General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock warned on Thursday that repeated deadlock in the Security Council has become the “poster child” for wider global gridlock, undermining trust in multilateral institutions.

item.title: What’s at stake in the COP30 negotiations?
item.description: Talks at the COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil, were suspended on Thursday after a fire broke out in the venue, triggering evacuations that halted negotiations between more than 190 delegations. The summit was set to conclude Friday, and the disruption came at a critical moment as countries were locked in tense debates over fossil fuels and climate finance. The outcome of these talks is widely seen as a litmus test for turning decades of climate pledges into concrete action.
item.source:markdown: Talks at the COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil, were suspended on Thursday after a fire broke out in the venue, triggering evacuations that halted negotiations between more than 190 delegations. The summit was set to conclude Friday, and the disruption came at a critical moment as countries were locked in tense debates over fossil fuels and climate finance. The outcome of these talks is widely seen as a litmus test for turning decades of climate pledges into concrete action.

item.title: U.S. ambassador resents meddling in foreign electoral politics, but Trump doesn't seem to mind doing so

item.title: Why the U.S. Justice Department and Congress may battle over redaction of Epstein files
item.description: When it comes to the Epstein files, there are solid reasons to withold certain information from the public, experts say. item.title: In the shadow of the Himalayas, this town is sinking, a casualty of the past and the present
item.description: Almost three years ago, hundreds of residents in Joshimath, India, were forced to leave after deep cracks appeared in the walls of some 800 homes because the ground was sinking around them. The town's location, climate change and heavy construction are being blamed.
item.source:markdown:
![Houses and other buildings are located at the bottom of a mountain range.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/3558d923-04f9-46d0-821c-3b469eaf4d93,1763588082114/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%281%2C0%2C4238%2C2383%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Almost three years ago, hundreds of residents in Joshimath, India, were forced to leave after deep cracks appeared in the walls of some 800 homes because the ground was sinking around them. The town's location, climate change and heavy construction are being blamed.

item.title: She lost 5 children during the war in Gaza — now she’s raising 36 grandkids in a tent
item.description: Reda Aliwa, 60, is caring for her 36 grandchildren in Gaza City after five of her own children were killed this September. Statistics suggest there are some 40,000 children in Gaza who’ve lost one or more parents, resulting in what one Palestinian organization has called “the largest orphan crisis in modern history.”
item.source:markdown:
![A woman in a black hijab sits in a dark tent as children play behind her. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b344396f-7c03-40c7-9b0a-b943e919b33f,1763611104438/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Reda Aliwa, 60, is caring for her 36 grandchildren in Gaza City after five of her own children were killed this September. Statistics suggest there are some 40,000 children in Gaza who’ve lost one or more parents, resulting in what one Palestinian organization has called “the largest orphan crisis in modern history.”

item.title: Listening to others out of love: Age is no barrier for religious sisters
item.description:
Although many religious congregations in Europe face the challenge of aging members, the heart of their vocation remains unchanged: to serve those in need with love and dedication. In Matera, in southern Italy, 93-year-old Sister Angela Sinopoli continues to do so on the streets of her city, living out her pastoral ministry of closeness.

Read all

item.title: ‘Parasocial’ is Cambridge Dictionary's word of the year
item.description: If you felt more excited for Taylor Swift’s engagement announcement earlier this year than you did for your friend or family member’s, you might relate to Cambridge Dictionary’s word of 2025: "parasocial," which describes having a one-sided connection with someone you do not know, such as a celebrity, a fictional character or an AI chatbot.

item.title: Ghana’s Catholic Bishops outline pastoral priorities
item.description:
The Ghana Catholic Bishops’ Conference (GCBC) has concluded its 2025 annual plenary assembly held in the Diocese of Damongo, during which key pastoral priorities and national concerns for the coming years were outlined. The assembly took place from 7 to 14 November under the theme “A Synodal Church at the Service of Justice and Peace in Ghana.”

item.title: Dozens of people die in DRC mine accident
item.description:
At least 32 people have been killed in southeastern Democratic Republic of Congo when a bridge at a copper and cobalt mine collapsed due to overcrowding. Enormous financial interests in the mineral-rich region have long fuelled strife and conflict, resulting in corruption, displacement and an acute humanitarian crisis.

item.title: On Brazil’s Combu Island, chocolate makers hold clues to climate action
item.description: Combu Island – Ilha do Combu in Portuguese – rises like a wall of living green from Brazil’s Guamá River. It is a testament to centuries of shared existence between the forest and its riverside communities. Here, cupuaçu, taperebá, pupunha, araçá and cacao are more than fruits; they are threads in the fabric of local culture, livelihoods and identity.
item.source:markdown: Combu Island – Ilha do Combu in Portuguese – rises like a wall of living green from Brazil’s Guamá River. It is a testament to centuries of shared existence between the forest and its riverside communities. Here, cupuaçu, taperebá, pupunha, araçá and cacao are more than fruits; they are threads in the fabric of local culture, livelihoods and identity.

Nothing less than charting a credible path to climate justice in a world running out of time.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: US hails ‘historic and constructive resolution’ on Gaza
item.description: The Security Council has passed a US-backed resolution which will establish an international force to restore order in Gaza, protect civilians and open the way for large-scale aid and rebuilding. There were 13 votes for, none against – while Russia and China abstained amid concerns that Russia might veto the text. US ambassador Mike Waltz thanked ambassadors, hailing it as an “historic and constructive resolution” which charts a new course for the Middle East. Follow live below, check out full meetings coverage here, and UN News app users, follow here.

item.title: Synod: Interim reports of Study Groups published
item.description:
Established by Pope Francis in March 2024, the Study Groups have delivered reports on the work carried out so far, starting from the conclusion of the Synod on Synodality. The deadline for delivering the final reports to Leo XIV has been set for 31 December. Among the topics covered are the digital mission, the role of women, ecumenism, polygamy, liturgy, the ministry of nuncios, and the selection of bishops.

item.title: Mexican government pursues second-shooter theory in 1994 political assassination that shook country
item.description: The March 23, 1994, death of Luis Donaldo Colosio, a reformer on the cusp of winning the Mexican presidency who promised a more just and democratic country, holds a space in the country's consciousness like the 1963 killing of President John F. Kennedy does in the United States. Federal authorities in Mexico recently arrested a 64-year-old man in Tijuana in connection with Colosio’s killing.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Vatican returns Indigenous cultural items to Canada's Catholic bishops on a 'historic day'
item.description: A century-old Inuvialuit kayak once used for beluga and whale hunts, and 61 other cultural objects from First Nations, Métis and Inuit communities have long been held in Vatican Museums vaults. But the items will be returned to Canada on Dec. 6 after Pope Leo on Saturday gifted them to a delegation of Catholic bishops.

A century-old Inuvialuit kayak once used for beluga and whale hunts, and 61 other cultural objects from First Nations, Métis and Inuit communities have long been held in Vatican Museums vaults. But the items will be returned to Canada on Dec. 6 after Pope Leo on Saturday gifted them to a delegation of Catholic bishops.

item.title: Indigenous protesters block COP30 entrance, demand action from Brazilian Government
item.description: Around 90 Indigenous people from the Munduruku Indigenous group staged a peaceful protest early Friday, blocking the main entrance to the Blue Zone – the restricted area set aside for negotiators – at COP30 in Belém. Access was halted for about an hour, and the army was called in to reinforce security.
item.source:markdown: Around 90 Indigenous people from the Munduruku Indigenous group staged a peaceful protest early Friday, blocking the main entrance to the Blue Zone – the restricted area set aside for negotiators – at COP30 in Belém. Access was halted for about an hour, and the army was called in to reinforce security.

item.description: Mu’ayyad Ajjour and his neighbour Mohamed Zaida have searched every day among the ruins of a building, hoping to find the remains of five-year-old Masa, Ajjour's cousin, so they can give her a proper burial. item.description: Since last fall, more than 12,000 North Koreans have reportedly been deployed to fight with the Russian army in Ukraine. Special correspondent Simon Ostrovsky investigates the reliance on mercenaries in the world's deadliest conflicts. PBS News is supported by - https://www.pbs.org/newshour/about/funders. item.title: A glimpse at the just-released “Leo from Chicago”
item.description:
Here’s a first look at the Vatican’s newly released documentary Leo from Chicago, which explores the roots of Pope Leo XIV and offers never-before-seen footage of Robert Francis Prevost in his native United States. The film features in-depth interviews with his brothers, Louis and John Prevost, and reveals new personal details — including what he looks forward to most on Thanksgiving, and how even as a boy he was able to turn 'an unruly little mob into friends.'

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Here’s a first look at the Vatican’s newly released documentary Leo from Chicago, which explores the roots of Pope Leo XIV and offers never-before-seen footage of Robert Francis Prevost in his native United States. The film features in-depth interviews with his brothers, Louis and John Prevost, and reveals new personal details — including what he looks forward to most on Thanksgiving, and how even as a boy he was able to turn 'an unruly little mob into friends.'
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/the-vatican-s-leo-from-chicago-is-out-here-s-a-glimpse.html)

item.title: From Haiti to Ethiopia: voices of climate displacement at COP30
item.description: Floods, heatwaves, droughts and storms are forcing millions from their homes every year. Most never cross a border; they remain internally displaced yet uprooted all the same. item.title: The hospital boats continuing Pope Francis' legacy in the Amazon
item.description:
On the sidelines of COP30 in Belém, Brazil, hospital boats are docked on the riverside, offering medical assistance to those most in need. The boats, inspired by Pope Francis, travel all along the Amazon River to tend to the needs to Indigenous communities and those who live along the river, far from cities. This is the testimony of Felipe, a volunteer doctor.

item.title: Taiwan evacuates residents trapped by flooding as tropical storm approaches
item.description: Taiwan evacuated more than 8,000 people from coastal and mountainous areas and closed schools ahead of the arrival of tropical storm Fung-wong. In Yilan County, rescue workers ferried people using boats and amphibious vehicles after torrential rains triggered severe flooding, and residents worked to clear debris and water from their homes.
item.source:markdown:
![People in bright, reflective clothing are being offered a pole to help pull them out of the water on a stormy night.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/8736064d-47dc-44a6-ac2f-ef46c2d7ee1c,1762978161646/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%289%2C0%2C1531%2C861%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Taiwan evacuated more than 8,000 people from coastal and mountainous areas and closed schools ahead of the arrival of tropical storm Fung-wong. item.description:
In a message to an international conference in Rome, Cardinal Pietro Parolin warns that humanity risks “its own extinction” if artificial life forms fail to respect human dignity, and he calls for interdisciplinary and multicultural cooperation to guide technology toward true human progress.

item.description: The UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and World Food Programme (WFP) warn of a major hunger emergency, with acute food insecurity set to worsen in 16 countries and territories between now and May 2026, putting millions of lives at risk.

item.source:markdown: Tuberculosis, or TB, remains one of the world’s deadliest infectious killers, claiming over 1.2 million lives and affecting an estimated 10.7 million people last year, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Wednesday.

item.title: ‘A wave of truth’: COP30 targets disinformation threat to climate action
item.description: Negotiators in Belém, Brazil, opened COP30 with a stark warning: the race to avert catastrophic global heating is being sabotaged by a surge of climate disinformation. The falsehoods, spreading faster than ever online, threaten to derail fragile progress on climate action.

item.description:
In his catechesis, Pope Leo highlights the importance of fraternity in our lives and describes it as something "deeply human". He explains that even though today's wars, tensions, and conflicts make fraternity seem difficult, without it, "we would not be able to survive, grow, or learn."

item.title: French foreign minister, at G7 meeting in Canada, says U.S. boat strikes violate international law
item.description: During a G7 meeting in Ontario, France's foreign affairs minister said the deadly boat strikes in the Caribbean carried out by the United States since early September violate international law. Colombia, California's governor and the Washington Post also weighed in on the strikes on Tuesday — but Canada has been relatively silent on the U.S. actions.
item.source:markdown:
![Two men in suit and tie stand on either side of a woman in a maroon pant suit and scarf.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/07ef49d3-5a7e-45c2-8776-9c4eac951eed,1762952395487/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C180%2C8256%2C4644%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
During a G7 meeting in Ontario, France's foreign affairs minister said the deadly boat strikes in the Caribbean carried out by the United States since early September violate international law. Colombia, California's governor and the Washington Post also weighed in on the strikes on Tuesday — but Canada has been relatively silent on the U.S. actions.

item.title: U.S. tourism faces $5.7B US loss as Canadians continue to stay home
item.description: Many Canadians continue to boycott travel to the United States, and the U.S. economy is paying the price. item.title: Swedish king’s visit highlights growing Canadian interest in Saab military aircraft
item.description: A few days before the federal budget was tabled, the CEO of Swedish industrial giant Saab flew to Ottawa to meet with the country's top bureaucrat, fuelling the sense a deal is brewing between the Canadian government and the military manufacturer. Now, the country's king, queen and a delegation of political and business leaders are set to visit from Nov. 18-20.

item.title: We have much to learn from our persecuted brothers and sisters in Africa
item.description:
Over the weekend, Pope Leo XIV speaking during the Saturday Jubilee Audience on 8 November 2025, in Saint Peter Square, reflected on the life of Blessed Isidore Bakanja, a young Congolese martyr. The testimony of Bakanja, “reminds us that we have much to learn from our persecuted brothers and sisters in Africa,” said Pope Leo XIV.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Hurricane Melissa death toll rises to 45 in Jamaica, with 15 others still missing
item.description: The number of confirmed deaths from Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica rose to 45, with 15 other people missing, authorities said Tuesday. The death toll is expected to rise, with officials still trying to reach two towns that remain cut off since the catastrophic Category 5 storm made landfall in western Jamaica on Oct. 28.
item.source:markdown:
![People standing amid wreckage](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/684fb96c-51dd-428f-b465-26658ebaa992,1762888277420/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C237%2C4552%2C2560%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The number of confirmed deaths from Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica rose to 45, with 15 other people missing, authorities said Tuesday. The death toll is expected to rise, with officials still trying to reach two towns that remain cut off since the catastrophic Category 5 storm made landfall in western Jamaica on Oct. 28.

item.title: Keeping cool on a hotter planet: COP30 pushes for sustainable cooling and AI innovation
item.description: As the planet heats up, so does the race for smarter, cleaner technology. At COP30 in Belém, Brazil, delegates are weighing a paradox at the heart of climate innovation: how to harness powerful tools like artificial intelligence (AI) and advanced cooling systems without deepening the very crisis they aim to solve.
item.source:markdown: As the planet heats up, so does the race for smarter, cleaner technology. item.title: US Senate passes bill to end government shutdown
item.description: The US Senate has approved a compromise that would end the longest government shutdown in US history, breaking a weeks-long stalemate that has disrupted food benefits for millions and left hundreds of thousands of federal workers unpaid.
item.source:markdown: The US Senate has approved a compromise that would end the longest government shutdown in US history, breaking a weeks-long stalemate that has disrupted food benefits for millions and left hundreds of thousands of federal workers unpaid.

item.title: Suicide bomber attacks outside Islamabad court, killing 12: Pakistan’s interior minister
item.description: Pakistan’s interior minister says a suicide bomber detonated his explosives near a police vehicle outside the gate of a district court in the capital, Islamabad, on Tuesday, killing 12 people and wounding 27.

item.title: 2 dead after small plane on hurricane relief mission to Jamaica crashes in Florida neighbourhood
item.description: A small turboprop plane on a hurricane relief mission to Jamaica crashed Monday morning into a pond in a gated residential neighbourhood of the Fort Lauderdale suburb of Coral Springs, killing two people shortly after takeoff and narrowly missing homes, authorities and a local resident said.

item.title: "Leo from Chicago" - The Documentary
item.description:
The Vatican Dicastery for Communication presents the documentary "Leo from Chicago," with interviews, footage, and images that trace the history and explore the roots of Robert Francis Prevost in his native United States, including in-depth interviews with Louis and John Prevost. A production by journalists Deborah Castellano Lubov, Salvatore Cernuzio, and Felipe Herrera-Espaliat.

item.title: Murder trial hears of boy's severe brain injuries
item.description: A State pathologist has told the Central Criminal Court that injuries to the brain of a four-year-old boy, whose stepmother is accused of his murder, were consistent with someone shaking the child as well as forcefully striking his head against a hard object like a wall or floor.

item.title: Tanzania: Church prays and hopes for reconciliation and peace
item.description:
As street protests affect Tanzania, the Archdiocese of Mbeya has been among the hardest hit, with more than a hundred victims. Fr. Valerio Mwandanji, parish priest of St. Matthew the Apostle Church, says a Mass was celebrated on 9 November “to remember those who lost their lives during the demonstrations. The people are calling for change.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Sarkozy released from jail 'nightmare' pending appeal

item.title: U.S. Supreme Court rejects bid to overturn same-sex marriage ruling
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court rejected on Monday a bid by a former Kentucky county official to overturn its landmark 2015 ruling legalizing same-sex marriage nationwide, as the justices steered clear of the contentious case some 3-1/2 years after its conservative majority reversed abortion rights.

The U.S. Supreme Court rejected on Monday a bid by a former Kentucky county official to overturn its landmark 2015 ruling legalizing same-sex marriage nationwide, as the justices steered clear of the contentious case some 3-1/2 years after its conservative majority reversed abortion rights.

item.title: 8 people dead in car explosion near Red Fort in New Delhi
item.description: At least eight people were killed on Monday in a car explosion near the historic Red Fort in a densely populated area of the Indian capital of New Delhi, a police spokesperson said. It was a rare blast in the heavily guarded city of more than 30 million people.
item.source:markdown:
![Emergency crews at the site of a car explosion.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b62f5166-3b83-4cd1-83c0-8eb5fa3241e4,1762789636014/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C292%2C5616%2C3159%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
At least eight people were killed on Monday in a car explosion near the historic Red Fort in a densely populated area of the Indian capital of New Delhi, a police spokesperson said. It was a rare blast in the heavily guarded city of more than 30 million people.

item.title: Typhoon Fung-wong blows away from Philippines, leaving 4 dead and 1.4 million displaced
item.description: Typhoon Fung-wong blew out of the northwestern Philippines on Monday after setting off floods and landslides, knocking out power to entire provinces, killing at least four people and displacing more than 1.4 million others

item.title: Brazil straddles oil riches, climate threats as COP30 opens in Amazon
item.description: In Oiapoque, Brazil, hopes that oil will transform the economy hangs in air, after the government granted state-owned company Petrobras an exploratory license off the remote Amazonian city's coast. item.title: Hall of Famer and former Raptors coach Lenny Wilkens dies at 88
item.description: Lenny Wilkens, a three-time inductee into the Basketball Hall of Fame who was enshrined as both a player and a coach, has died, his family said Sunday. He was 88. The family said Wilkens was surrounded by loved ones when he died and did not immediately release a cause of death.

item.title: Trump administration wants U.S. states to 'undo' full payouts of food aid benefits
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration is demanding states "undo" full SNAP food benefits paid out under judges' orders over the past week, now that the U.S. Supreme Court has stayed those rulings — marking the latest swing in a seesawing legal battle over the anti-hunger program used by 42 million Americans.

item.title: Pope at Angelus: We are Christ's Church meant to joyfully walk with Him
item.description:
During his weekly Angelus address, Pope Leo XIV reminds the faithful that "the true sanctuary of God is Christ" who is "the only mediator of salvation, the only Redeemer, the One who, by uniting Himself with our humanity, and transforming us with His love, represents the door that opens wide for us and leads us to the Father."

Read all
item.source:markdown:
During his weekly Angelus address, Pope Leo XIV reminds the faithful that "the true sanctuary of God is Christ" who is "the only mediator of salvation, the only Redeemer, the One who, by uniting Himself with our humanity, and transforming us with His love, represents the door that opens wide for us and leads us to the Father."

item.title: Pope: The Church is a ‘construction site’ for a community to be built without haste
item.description:
Celebrating Mass on the occasion of the Dedication of the Basilica of St John Lateran, Pope Leo XIV reflects on the Church, urging the faithful to be ‘free from the criteria of the world, which too often demands immediate results because it does not know the wisdom of waiting’. ‘Jesus changes us and calls us to work in God's great construction site, wisely shaping us according to His plans for salvation.’ ‘In Rome,’ says the Pope, ‘there is a great good that grows’ beyond the hardships.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Celebrating Mass on the occasion of the Dedication of the Basilica of St John Lateran, Pope Leo XIV reflects on the Church, urging the faithful to be ‘free from the criteria of the world, which too often demands immediate results because it does not know the wisdom of waiting’. ‘Jesus changes us and calls us to work in God's great construction site, wisely shaping us according to His plans for salvation.’ ‘In Rome,’ says the Pope, ‘there is a great good that grows’ beyond the hardships.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/pope-the-church-is-a-building-site.html)

item.title: Six months with Pope Leo XIV: A united and open Church, a sign of peace for a world wounded by hatred
item.description:
There is a common thread running through the magisterium of the new Pope: he has proposed a model of Christian community, missionary in nature, where communion is lived, and which is therefore capable of serving all, starting with the least; a community committed to fostering dialogue and peace. A Church that does not “lean” on the powerful nor confuse mission with religious marketing, but knows how to be leaven because it reflects the light of Another.

Read all

item.title: Vatican: Altarpiece installed in the Church of the Teutonic Cemetery
item.description:
The work by German artist Michael Triegel, on display in the church near St Peter’s, depicts among its figures a homeless man who once posed for the artist and is now buried in the adjacent cemetery. The altarpiece, which will be on display for two years, is a sign of ecumenical dialogue.

item.title: Trump administration fights court ruling to pay food assistance to 42 million amid shutdown

item.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi brings rain and destruction to Vietnam as death toll nears 190 in Philippines
item.description: At least five people died in Vietnam after Typhoon Kalmaegi pummelled coastal regions with destructive winds and heavy rain, officials said on Friday, following the storm's deadly passage through the Philippines where it killed at least 188 people.

At least five people died in Vietnam after Typhoon Kalmaegi pummelled coastal regions with destructive winds and heavy rain, officials said on Friday, following the storm's deadly passage through the Philippines where it killed at least 188 people.

item.title: Afghanistan: Opium cultivation drops sharply, but regional trafficking rises
item.description: Opium poppy cultivation in Afghanistan has fallen by 20 per cent compared to last year, continuing a dramatic decline since the introduction of a nationwide ban under the Taliban in 2022 – but synthetic drugs and shifting trafficking routes are posing new challenges.
item.source:markdown: Opium poppy cultivation in Afghanistan has fallen by 20 per cent compared to last year, continuing a dramatic decline since the introduction of a nationwide ban under the Taliban in 2022 – but synthetic drugs and shifting trafficking routes are posing new challenges.

item.title: New Brazil-led fund aims to put forest protection at the heart of climate action
item.description: Tropical forests, vital allies in the fight against climate breakdown, are vanishing at an alarming rate. On Thursday, in a bid to help reverse this trend, Brazil launched a new initiative at a summit of world leaders in Belém, the gateway to the Amazon.
item.source:markdown: Tropical forests, vital allies in the fight against climate breakdown, are vanishing at an alarming rate. On Thursday, in a bid to help reverse this trend, Brazil launched a new initiative at a summit of world leaders in Belém, the gateway to the Amazon.

item.title: UN chief urges world leaders to drive down global warming
item.description: As world leaders gather in Brazil for the COP30 climate summit, UN Secretary-General António Guterres on Thursday called for urgent action to drive down global temperatures and keep the 1.5°C goal within reach.
item.source:markdown: As world leaders gather in Brazil for the COP30 climate summit, UN Secretary-General António Guterres on Thursday called for urgent action to drive down global temperatures and keep the 1.5°C goal within reach.

item.title: Doha summit ends with call to turn social pledges into action
item.description: The Second World Summit for Social Development concluded in Doha on Thursday with calls for countries to move swiftly from commitments to implementation, ensuring that the Doha Political Declaration delivers measurable progress on poverty reduction, decent work and social inclusion.
item.source:markdown: The Second World Summit for Social Development concluded in Doha on Thursday with calls for countries to move swiftly from commitments to implementation, ensuring that the Doha Political Declaration delivers measurable progress on poverty reduction, decent work and social inclusion.

item.title: Israel has rejected over 100 aid requests since Gaza ceasefire, UN says
item.description: The United Nations said on Thursday that Israeli authorities have rejected more than 100 requests to bring relief materials into Gaza since the ceasefire began nearly a month ago.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations said on Thursday that Israeli authorities have rejected more than 100 requests to bring relief materials into Gaza since the ceasefire began nearly a month ago.

item.title: Battlefields to wastelands: UN warns conflicts are destroying ecosystems worldwide
item.description: From Gaza to Ukraine and beyond, conflict has caused widespread death and destruction, but it has also devastated natural resources such as water systems, farmland and forests.
item.source:markdown: From Gaza to Ukraine and beyond, conflict has caused widespread death and destruction, but it has also devastated natural resources such as water systems, farmland and forests.

item.title: Grandi calls for greater refugee protection and funding
item.description: The UN High Commissioner for Refugees appealed on Thursday for more solutions to address forced displacement in his final address to the General Assembly.
item.source:markdown: The UN High Commissioner for Refugees appealed on Thursday for more solutions to address forced displacement in his final address to the General Assembly.

item.title: Security Council lifts terror-related sanctions on Syrian President
item.description: The Security Council on Thursday adopted a resolution to remove Syria’s transitional President Ahmed al-Sharaa and Interior Minister Anas Khattab from sanctions measures targeting members and supporters of terrorist groups ISIL and Al-Qaida.
item.source:markdown: The Security Council on Thursday adopted a resolution to remove Syria’s transitional President Ahmed al-Sharaa and Interior Minister Anas Khattab from sanctions measures targeting members and supporters of terrorist groups ISIL and Al-Qaida.

item.title: Nearly a third of Jamaica’s annual wealth wiped out by Hurricane Melissa
item.description: Around 1.5 million Jamaicans have been impacted by Hurricane Melissa – the worst climate disaster in the Caribbean nation’s history, said the top UN development official in the region on Thursday.
item.source:markdown: Around 1.5 million Jamaicans have been impacted by Hurricane Melissa – the worst climate disaster in the Caribbean nation’s history, said the top UN development official in the region on Thursday.

item.title: Genocide prevention expert raises alarm over alleged Sudan atrocity crimes
item.description: The UN Special Adviser on genocide prevention has raised concerns over widespread allegations of war crimes committed in Sudan’s El Fasher last month, and plans to meet his African Union counterpart on Friday to discuss a coordinated response.
item.source:markdown: The UN Special Adviser on genocide prevention has raised concerns over widespread allegations of war crimes committed in Sudan’s El Fasher last month, and plans to meet his African Union counterpart on Friday to discuss a coordinated response.

item.title: Doha: World Summit ends with renewed pledge to leave no one behind
item.description: The Second World Summit for Social Development wrapped up on Thursday with nations warning that global progress on poverty and inequality will stall unless countries move faster from promises to implementation.
item.source:markdown: The Second World Summit for Social Development wrapped up on Thursday with nations warning that global progress on poverty and inequality will stall unless countries move faster from promises to implementation.

item.title: Boeing officially off the hook for criminal charges in deadly crashes that killed 346 people
item.description: A U.S. judge on Thursday approved a request by the Justice Department to dismiss a criminal case against Boeing stemming from two fatal 737 MAX plane crashes that killed 346 people including 18 Canadians.
item.source:markdown:
![A company logo is shown on a wall, it reads 'Boeing.'](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/d9ccee04-2484-4e8f-b204-1e442dc0241b,1762445873600/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C300%2C5760%2C3240%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A U.S. judge on Thursday approved a request by the Justice Department to dismiss a criminal case against Boeing stemming from two fatal 737 MAX plane crashes that killed 346 people including 18 Canadians.

item.title: Central Bank fines Coinbase Europe €21.5m for breaches
item.description: The Central Bank has fined cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Europe €21.5m for breaching anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing transaction monitoring obligations.
item.source:markdown: The Central Bank has fined cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Europe €21.5m for breaching anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing transaction monitoring obligations.

item.title: Pope meets with Palestinian President, says action on Gaza is 'urgent'
item.description:
Pope Leo meets with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, discussing the “urgent need” for an end to the conflict in Gaza and for the entry of humanitarian aid.

item.title: Israel declares Egypt border area a closed military zone
item.description: Israeli Defence Minister Israel Katz has said he instructed the army to turn the area at the border with Egypt into a closed military zone to combat weapons smuggling via drones.
item.source:markdown: Israeli Defence Minister Israel Katz has said he instructed the army to turn the area at the border with Egypt into a closed military zone to combat weapons smuggling via drones.

item.title: Louvre robbery a 'deafening wake-up call', says auditor
item.description: Last month's spectacular Louvre robbery, in which thieves made off with some of France's crown jewels, is a "deafening wake-up call" for museum security, the head of France's highest audit institution has said.
item.source:markdown: Last month's spectacular Louvre robbery, in which thieves made off with some of France's crown jewels, is a "deafening wake-up call" for museum security, the head of France's highest audit institution has said.

item.title: Referendum on Triple Lock not necessary, says Tánaiste
item.description: The Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs and Defence has said that he does not believe a referendum is necessary to change the Triple Lock.
item.source:markdown: The Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs and Defence has said that he does not believe a referendum is necessary to change the Triple Lock.

item.title: Sudan's paramilitary force agrees to U.S. proposal for humanitarian ceasefire
item.description: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) agreed to a proposal from the United States for a humanitarian ceasefire, the group said on Thursday in a statement.

item.title: Pope: New Charta Oecumenica shows shared journey of European Churches
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV meets with signatories to the new Charta Oecumenica, and invites European Bishops of various Christian Churches to listen to one another in order to preach the Gospel of Christ more effectively.

item.title: Two arrested in Drogheda IPAS centre fire investigation
item.description: Two men in their 20s have been arrested in connection with the investigation into a fire at a building housing International Protection applicants in Co Louth on Halloween night.
item.source:markdown: Two men in their 20s have been arrested in connection with the investigation into a fire at a building housing International Protection applicants in Co Louth on Halloween night.

item.title: Further bird flu outbreaks will be 'devastating' - farmer
item.description: A poultry farmer in east Cork has warned "it will be devastating" if there are more outbreaks of the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain of avian influenza on commercial farms.
item.source:markdown: A poultry farmer in east Cork has warned "it will be devastating" if there are more outbreaks of the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain of avian influenza on commercial farms.

item.title: Cartel-fighting mayor’s assassination in Mexico’s avocado heartland fuels citizen fury
item.description: Uruapan Mayor Carlos Manzo’s killing triggered a spasm of fury that has fuelled protests across the fertile Mexican state of Michoacan, which produces limes and avocados found on Canadian grocery shelves.

item.title: What is bird flu and how concerning is the spread?
item.description: The Department of Agriculture has imposed a mandatory housing order for poultry and captive birds, effective from 10 November, following the first outbreak of highly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu on a farm in the country since 2022.
item.source:markdown: The Department of Agriculture has imposed a mandatory housing order for poultry and captive birds, effective from 10 November, following the first outbreak of highly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu on a farm in the country since 2022.

item.title: Mary Ward’s vision fulfilled as two congregations merge
item.description:
Venerable Mary Ward, foundress of the spiritual family that would become the Congregation of Jesus (CJ) and the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary (IBVM, the Loreto Sisters), long desired that her followers be one body. That vision has effectively been realized this week, as the two congregations, present in over 40 countries, are now united as a single institute.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Venerable Mary Ward, foundress of the spiritual family that would become the Congregation of Jesus (CJ) and the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary (IBVM, the Loreto Sisters), long desired that her followers be one body. That vision has effectively been realized this week, as the two congregations, present in over 40 countries, are now united as a single institute.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-11/becoming-one-mary-ward-s-vision-fulfilled-as-two-congregations.html)

item.title: Prisoner mistakenly released in UK turns himself in
item.description: One of two prisoners mistakenly released from Wandsworth Prison in England has handed himself back in, while the hunt continues for another prisoner also released in error.
item.source:markdown: One of two prisoners mistakenly released from Wandsworth Prison in England has handed himself back in, while the hunt continues for another prisoner also released in error.

item.title: French auditor's report raps Louvre for excessive art acquisitions even as most rooms lacked cameras
item.description: France's Louvre Museum began a security audit a decade ago but the recommended upgrades will not be completed until 2032, the state auditor said in a report on Thursday compiled before a spectacular heist there last month.
item.source:markdown:
![Several people are shown with backs to the camera pointing their phones at pieces of art and paintings on the wall of a museum.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1e0a1fcd-93cc-491c-9619-35c11ef18f9c,1762429489469/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C3923%2C2206%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
France's Louvre Museum began a security audit a decade ago but the recommended upgrades will not be completed until 2032, the state auditor said in a report on Thursday compiled before a spectacular heist there last month.

item.title: At least 142 dead in Philippines after Typhoon Kalmaegi
item.description: Typhoon Kalmaegi has made landfall in central Vietnam after killing at least 142 people in the Philippines and unleashing devastating flooding.
item.source:markdown: Typhoon Kalmaegi has made landfall in central Vietnam after killing at least 142 people in the Philippines and unleashing devastating flooding.

item.title: Typhoon hits Vietnam after killing 140 in Philippines
item.description: Typhoon Kalmaegi made landfall in Vietnam's already storm-battered central belt today, where thousands have been evacuated from areas in the path of one of the world's deadliest cyclones this year.
item.source:markdown: Typhoon Kalmaegi made landfall in Vietnam's already storm-battered central belt today, where thousands have been evacuated from areas in the path of one of the world's deadliest cyclones this year.

item.title: Vietnam evacuates hundreds of thousands as Typhoon Kalmaegi lands after leaving 114 dead in Philippines
item.description: Typhoon Kalmaegi slammed into Vietnam on Thursday, forcing authorities to cancel hundreds of flights and order people to stay indoors, two days after the storm started sweeping across the Philippines, killing at least 114 people.
item.source:markdown:
![Significant waves in a body of water are shown on a dreary-looking day with high-rises in the background.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/07a5b3e2-0ab8-433f-826e-181e39007454,1762453156049/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C708%2C6796%2C3822%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Typhoon Kalmaegi slammed into Vietnam on Thursday, forcing authorities to cancel hundreds of flights and order people to stay indoors, two days after the storm started sweeping across the Philippines, killing at least 114 people.

item.title: Plan to enhance Irish learning in schools announced

item.title: Defective block strategy for Donegal schools under way
item.description: The Department of Education and Youth is preparing a strategy to help schools that are waiting for defective concrete block remediation as well as schools that may be affected in the future.
item.source:markdown: The Department of Education and Youth is preparing a strategy to help schools that are waiting for defective concrete block remediation as well as schools that may be affected in the future.

item.title: Call for intense focus on biosecurity amid bird flu cases
item.description: The Irish Farmers' Association has called on poultry flock owners across the country to adopt a "laser-like focus on biosecurity" after confirmation yesterday of a case of avian influenza, or bird flu, on a second commercial turkey farm.
item.source:markdown: The Irish Farmers' Association has called on poultry flock owners across the country to adopt a "laser-like focus on biosecurity" after confirmation yesterday of a case of avian influenza, or bird flu, on a second commercial turkey farm.

item.title: US and China were once united on climate, no longer
item.description: A little more than ten years ago, the US and China's joint commitment to combat climate change paved the way for the Paris Agreement. Now the US has turned its back on climate policy while China forges ahead with renewables. Will the world have to choose between the petrostate and the electrostate?
item.source:markdown: A little more than ten years ago, the US and China's joint commitment to combat climate change paved the way for the Paris Agreement. Now the US has turned its back on climate policy while China forges ahead with renewables. Will the world have to choose between the petrostate and the electrostate?

item.description: World leaders are meeting in Belém in Brazil in advance of the biggest climate summit of the year - COP30.
item.source:markdown: World leaders are meeting in Belém in Brazil in advance of the biggest climate summit of the year - COP30.

item.title: 10% of flights cut at 40 US airports over govt shutdown
item.description: US officials have said the scheduled capacity for flights would be cut by 10% from tomorrow in 40 busy air traffic areas of the country, with an ongoing government shutdown causing major staffing issues.
item.source:markdown: US officials have said the scheduled capacity for flights would be cut by 10% from tomorrow in 40 busy air traffic areas of the country, with an ongoing government shutdown causing major staffing issues.

item.title: 'We have to go further', Taoiseach tells COP30

item.title: AI jobs doubled in Ireland since 2023 - report
item.description: A new report from a Government advisory group has found that artificial intelligence jobs have doubled in Ireland since 2023.
